Comments_List: Learned a lot of probability fundamentals. This course has a focus on theory. You build up through Monte Carlo method from counting. You are better prepared for probability problems for interviews and for future statistics-based classes.
Lots about PDFs, PMFs, CDFs, and the whole lot of them. Some really cool distributions as well.
insight into what probability theory actually is - way more theoretical than might be suggested by high school courses in statistics
Distributions, LOTUS, PMF, CDF

I learned some statistics. I had taken STAT 100 before and this class treated topics such as random variables, distributions, conditional probability, Bayes' rule in more detail and introduced me to the Law of Total Probability,  the Law of the Unconscious Statistician, covariance and correlation. I was introduced to many new notions in this class, however, we could have covered them more slowly and in greater depth, understanding more of their details.
I taught myself some degree of probability theory because I took this class.
probability
I learned theorems and applications of probability.

This class provided me with the fundamentals of various topics in probability and statistics. I found it to be more helpful than introductory level statistics in terms of actually understanding concepts rather than just memorizing them.
I learned a great deal about statistical methods and how to solve complex probability questions with unique distributions, sometimes in 2D.
Probability theory!
useful basis for stats

Basic probability (counting), random variables, discrete PMFs, continous CDFs and PDFs, expectation, variance, random walks, correlation, joint/marginal distribution, probability inequalities, Central Limit Theorem.

Most importantly, I developed a probabilistic intuition which helps me reason through counting problems and gut check calculations. We worked through discrete and continuous probability problems that were applicable and to some degree justified by in-class proofs.
This was my first probability class, and I learned the basic theorems of probability.
Probability
I learned the basics of continuous probability.
Set theory, discrete and continuous distributions, expectation/variance, and how to apply these to practical problems.
This span of this course's content is quite intense. First half of the semester will focus on discrete probabilities, second half on continuous random variables.
I learned a lot of basic foundational theory in probability which is extremely important for many areas of data science.
How to think about probability and model uncertain events
What knowledge, skills, and insights did YOU develop by taking this course?

I learned about discrete probability (including counting, random variables (bernoulli, binomial, geometric, poisson), expectation, variance, random walks, and more) and continuous probability (including various distributions (uniform, exponential, normal), transformations, central limit theorem, moment generating functions, and more). There were proofs in class, and a few smaller ones on the homeworks, but mostly it was about concepts and a lot of calculations (pencil and paper calculations-- this class does not use R or Matlab or any other computational statistics program).
I learned about introductory concepts in probability.
This course covered a good amount of intro probability and forced me to think differently from other math classes I've taken like multivariable.
I learned many important mathematical techniques used in probability. Through this course, I gained the skill of wrapping my head around difficult problems in terms of simple probabilistic concepts.
Probability
It's an introduction to probability theory.  You'll formalize a lot of intuitive probability concepts as well as learn about a number of different distributions and their properties.

Basically the sum total of my knowledge (which is albeit not very much...) of discrete and continuous probability. Counting questions... fun puzzles... an understanding of continuous distributions, etc.
The basics of Probability. Every STEM student should take this class, it's so foundational.
I did not learn anything because this class was taught poorly. After finishing this course, I feel that I have not gained any information. It was a waste of a course
Fundamental probability theory.

I learned a lot about probability, and appreciate all the intellectual challenge this class provided. A lot of the puzzles were very fun to do, and helped me learn a lot about the intuition behind probability.
Nothing

A good understanding of the most famous and relevant questions in probability theory - gambler's ruin, random walk, buffon's needle, and other story questions. Regarding the theory itself, the course does a decent job in introducing the basics and doesn't go too in depth, mostly due to the amount of time spent on problems. Unlike many other courses, this course with the G Yihong puts the focus on the problems, and deriving the course material essentially from the problems, the opposite of many other courses.

I rarely write a lot for these,  but I feel I have some form of civic duty to warn future students of this class. I was told this class enjoyable and interesting, especially for S&DS majors, but wow were those people wrong. I have never before been in a class where I genuinely do not think I learned a single thing. Professor Wu may do interesting research or something for Yale, but he should absolutely not be teaching intro probability. Quite frankly, I'm at a loss of how to even begin to describe how poor this class was. I think a good sign is that by the third week, maybe 25 students showed up to lectures because they were so unhelpful (this class was slated to be in Davies Aud, one of the largest halls on campus!). The slides were exclusively in set notation, which Professor Yu didn't even bother to explain at the begging of the course...this is a intro class, set notation is something people have not seen extensively. Further, the slides are basically a series of proofs with no context and very few practice problems to demonstrate concepts in an understandable, so for all intents and purposes the slides were completely useless. Lectures involve Professor Wu standing at the chalkboard with his back to the lecture hall, talking quietly, and writing proofs on the board. You could only hear him if you sat in the front few rows (which, to be fair, wasn't to hard considering no one ever was at class). I am thinking about majoring in S&DS but this class is making me reconsider that. We've gotten several articles from Yale this year about how they're putting tons of resources into the S&DS department, and if this is true I am shocked how this class could be so unbelievably poorly run. I had to teach myself everything in this class through watching Harvard and MIT lectures on YouTube. Additionally, we were given no feedback on problem sets and they were graded incredibly erratically. You would get one back and there'd be a couple answers circled with "-5" or something written on the page and you'd have not idea what went wrong since someone with the same answer got full credit for the problem.  I feel incredibly let down by the school. I could go on about this for far longer, but I'm on break and thinking more about this class is the last thing I want to do.
Discrete and Continuous Random Variables and their properties.

This course had the potential to properly teach extremely relevant, applicable, and interesting topics in probability theory; however, it utterly failed to accomplish this mission. Lecture slides were filled with abstract calculus and algebra that was presented without justification, relevant theorems and their corollaries were rarely stated and not emphasized, and no strategy for problem solving was ever taught. Professor Wu demonstrated a clear disregard for student comprehension of the material, instead he was content with lecturing non-stop for 75 minutes, rapidly clicking through slides, disregarding crucial steps as "simple calculus," and pretending as if he had taught the material. The only skills to be developed by taking this course is self-study and bravery, for problem sets rarely covered topics that the average student could answer alone or in study groups. The midterm was surprisingly easy but the final was excruciatingly difficult.

I learnt a lot but let me tell you that was all on me. This was the worst freaking class I have taken of all time with the worst professor. Please avoid all Yihong Wu classes. The material is interesting and not too complex, but you teach 97% of it to yourself. Most of my friends watched lectures on youtube of the Harvard version of this class because our lectures were so miserable and useless and saddening (except for the one time we had a guest lecturer). Office hours do not help. Section does not help. The professor is garbage, the TAs are garbage. I went into the final with a great grade so let me tell you this isn't even me being resentful. This is just a poorly taught class and you should avoid unless set on being an SDS major. Lecture is mostly slides of proofs that are useless when it comes to psets and tests: if i were to show you the psets/tests/lectures from this class separately you would be like: oh, these must be from three different classes! But no. This class in one word: emasculating. I gained the insight that I have good work ethic and am good at teaching myself things, that is all.
Basic knowledge about probability.
I learned the basics of counting and probability distributions.
Greater knowledge of probability theory, ability to do probability calculations
I learned how to go about probability problems.
I learned the basics of probability and reviewed some concepts from discrete math.

This course taught me the fundamentals of probability theory from the basic axioms up to proving the central limit theorem (following relatively closely most of Blitzstein and Hwang Chapters 1-10 while skipping some sections).
Almost nothing. This class covered material very quickly and at a deep level. It was extremely unengaging and most students in the class agree that little learning was done.
The class was great for learning probability and the concepts that support it. Pretty difficult though.
Basics of probability.  Honestly Yihong is such a terrible teacher we had to learn it all ourselves.
I got a general into to probability concepts, but nothing I couldnt have taught myself with YouTube tutorials.
I learned of the existence of many concepts.
Theoretical and practical understanding of probability. See syllabus.
The math behind stuff learned in AP Stat such as distributions, standard deviation, random variables
I think I learned basic concepts of  probability and got a feel of more advanced ones. I think I will be able to apply the knowledge gained in class in real life to some extent.

This class gave me an understanding of mathematical notions of probability and how to think about problems that deal with probability. I learned about the axioms of probability, random variables, expectation, variance, the common distributions of random variables, moment generating functions, and other topics. This class helped me improve my ability to think about probability problems which tend to not be intuitive.
Mostly self learning.
This is an interesting introduction into the world of probability theory.

The course taught the elements of probability theory. This includes the analysis of distributions, counting methods, expectation, conditioning and Bayes' theorem, the principles of inclusion and exclusion, the sum of independent random variables, normal distributions, arbitrary transformations and functions on distribution spaces, the law of large numbers, and the general central limit theorem. In some years, generating functions, branching processes and Markov chains are also taught. The course attempts to provide a fundamental basis in statistics and data analysis.
Theory behind probability and intuition of probability

I learned how to solve various problems in probability from discrete to continuous. Probability is an extremely useful tool and way of thinking. Every concept applies to real-world problems. Probability offers key insights into the nature of an object or the likelihood of an event. It is useful in estimation and optimization.
Discrete and continuous random variables and their properties are covered extensively in this course.

Good survey of the theory (as it says in the name) surrounding probability and statistics as a whole. I gained an appreciation for the subtlety of probability in this course, as well as an ability to solve problems without formulas and equations, but having to truly apply concepts.
I learnt basic probability theory
Probability distributions, interesting problems such as Buffon's Needle, Random Walk and Gambler's Ruin. Learnt how to self-learn new concepts and tackle challenging problems.
I learned the basic structures of probability, sample spaces, Baysian principles, and other related topics.

P-Sets are way too hard, professor was really unhelpful and rather rude, material is presented in a way that is not conducive to learning whatsoever.  Only strengths are that some of the ULAs are pretty good.
The content should be more evenly distributed; the latter half of the course felt very rushed, which is frustrating because the content is more difficult.

With Yihong, this class felt markedly harder than what I expected; many friends described 241 as a gut. But with this professor, it was much harder, although you ostensibly learned more; take that as you will. Fixing the disparity is a point for improvement.
The material was interesting. The PSETs were challenging in a good way.
-Lectures go over a lot of material, but often end up with extended proofs that may be hard to follow if you don't have much proof experience or exposure to higher level math.
Good instructions, faced past

In STAT 241, I did learn many concepts in statistics that I did not know before (e.g. creating a new random variable by applying a function transformation to the old one and the properties that this new random variable had, based on our knowledge of the old one). This course could have gone more slowly and in more detail. In many lectures we were running to cover as much as possible. It would have been better if we had discussed the concepts in depth in class. Some of the concepts that are related to mathematical analysis were not covered, but I think that is normal for the class, because it focuses on statistical notions, not analysis. The class could have gone more slowly. The book was good. It did not treat the mathematical aspects of the notions very much, however, the class itself did not seem very focused on the mathematical explanation of the notions.

The TAs and office hours are extremely helpful in completing the psets, and the psets themselves are challenging and interesting, going beyond direct memorization of techniques and encouraging creative problem solving. But the lectures are extremely hard to follow and do not include enough example problems that help you tackle homework problems/exams. Lecture is not an effective way to teach math classes, they should be taught in small classes where students work together and actively learn/solve problems during class. But that's not going to happen anytime soon so this class is sort of doing it's best.

This course was taught and reinforced well. There was a lot of content that was imbalanced between the two halves of the semester. Perhaps the pace of the first half could have been faster so that more content is covered for the midterm, and students can focus on less material for the second half.

The lectures for this class are all very clear and are posted online, which is helpful when studying for exams. The problem sets are usually much harder than the exams, although that is probably a good thing in terms of preparation. Some of the topics felt a bit detached from the rest, but those were the exception; otherwise, the class flowed well.

The lectures were always taught very well and covered interesting material. They always began with a review of the previous lecture, which I appreciated. However, the problem sets were extremely difficult, so most students ended up scrambling to go to office hours or ask their peers in order to get the solutions in time for the deadline. At least there were office hours almost every weekday. Additionally, the exams were very difficult and most people struggled with them.

Professor Wu readily took questions during class, which was helpful. The examples he did during class lecture (most during the first half of the semester) were also really useful, but he stopped doing examples toward the end of the semester which left a lot of concepts fairly confusing. There was also not that much preparation available for the midterm or final exams, as office hours were generally limited and he did not post answer keys for the practice final exams :(

The largest strength is that this course is structured well, with weekly psets that are always roughly the same length.  Unfortunately, everything else about this course was pretty bad.  Yihong is not a good lecturer, especially at 9AM, and his exams were brutal (the final average last time he taught this course was under 70).  I have no idea what my grade in this course will be.
final way too hard
Material was presented is a very linear and organized way. However, I thought the lectures could be very dry.

Lectures were very dry, but the slides themselves were very good. Problem sets were too short for the difficulty of the material, and the first half of the course was much easier than the second half of the course. There are a wide range of students in the class, so class time is wasted by elementary questions while Professor Wu rushes through some of the more complicated mathematical concepts in the class. It could be improved by lengthening problem sets. The problem sets themselves varied widely in difficulty.

The material is not that difficult, it is just that sometimes the professor would not explain things fully, and would write exams much more difficult than the average previous exam based on what we heard. Difficult content is expected, but in the presented format the final exam was near impossible.

Class was fair as were the midterms and homework, but the final exam was absurdly difficult to a degree I had never experienced before, as we were presented questions in manners we never learned to tackle in neither the notes nor the homework.
Release solutions to the practice tests please!
The lecture were slow (and at 9am) which was a weakness, and led to me not coming to class after the midterm. However, the lecture slides were clear and detailed, which was a strength.

Strengths: interesting material, organized lecture notes, problem sets were very helpful for the exams. Weaknesses: The concepts could have been explained more conceptually before diving straight into the proofs. I thought Yihong rushed through some important concepts (like transformations between different random variables, moment generating functions, CLT, etc.) so it would be beneficial to spend more time on these. Also, the final exam was much harder and longer than I expected.

Go deeper, don't learn the CLT and MGFs on the last two lectures of class, learn how to apply them better as they are the heavy-hitters of the class. Write a clear and easy to interpret final, as the questions were poorly written and vague.

The course should be made smaller and fewer material should be covered. Lectures should focus on more concrete examples rather than proofs as the class is not a proof-based class. Psets are extremely time-consuming and difficult, tying together all material covered before the student has even had a chance to properly learn the material. The structure of huge lectures and psets, 1 midterm and 1 final is a terrible way of promoting student learning. Students stress over psets and that only distracts the students from actually learning the material. Only 1 midterm assessing an entire half-semester's worth of material is not good either.

ULAs saved this course. They held office hours which were mostly used to work through problem sets, but they were very helpful in explaining how to think about a problem and answering questions along the way (perhaps because they have though about such problems recently, and can relate to our confusion). Yihong's slides are fantastic, but his teaching was challenging to follow. His problem sets are also fairly difficult, as was the midterm (if you haven't seen competition math and classic probability problems before) and final.
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?

A major weakness was that it was at 9am! It was so hard not to fall asleep in class at that hour. At least the slides (which were gorgeous and informative, by the way) were always posted. Another weakness is that I don't think any final exam should ever be that hard! I got the impression that I wasn't the only one who had huge struggles with it, so unless the averages prove me wrong, I do think that it needed to be better calibrated to the time allotted and our level of understanding. A strength was that Prof Wu was very clear in lecture and his slides, again, were beautiful and accessible, and he did make an effort to explain the significance of the concepts he was teaching. Another strength was that the TA and ULA office hours were super helpful. The problem sets could be very difficult but I knew that they were achievable if I went to office hours-- and with a bit (or maybe a lot) of help they were actually satisfying and helped me learn the concepts.

Weakness: The difficulty of the exams and some problem sets discourage people from being able to grasp the concepts of probability. There was also sometimes a lack of communication between the students and the professor, ULAs and TFs.

Yihong was a great lecturer (for those who managed to make the 9am wakeup) and his slides covering the material were SO incredibly helpful. The tests were very difficult (much harder than problem sets) and I hear that the average on the 2016 Final Exam was a 42%. Not sure why he makes them so hard (if I were a freshman and this were my first math class at Yale, that would be an awakening and a half). The class problem sets were very helpful and the textbook was a great supplement to lecture.
This course was very well structured. I felt as though I knew half of the material already. Perhaps a broader scope.
Lectures were not engaging and Yihong Wu feels like a robot. Final exam was the hardest math test I've taken in my entire life, and I think was unfair and other students felt the same.

The content of the course is very interesting, but Professor Wu struggled to communicate it. I stopped going to lecture 2/3rds of the way through the course, using the slides as a resource. These slides were okay, but could have more effort put into. Alternatively, in another math course of mine the professor posts a couple pages of concisely-written notes on the topic. This would have been much clearer for 241.
More guidance on homework

The problem sets were well written, weren't a horrible time commitment, but still solidified the skills every week.  I didn't think the lecture was super helpful.  I skipped a few times because of late nights and other homework but I didn't feel that behind.  The powerpoints from lecture on canvas were helpful, especially while reviewing for the final.

Strengths: the slides are very well organized, the psets are pretty fun and fair, very fair midterm, lots of practice midterms/finals available to study, TAs are helpful during office hours
weaknesses: Moves way, way too fast during the second half. Continuous probability distributions are a lot to deal with harder than discrete probability distributions, but we moved maybe twice as fast when studying continuous probability. The course might benefit from moving less slowly at the beginning and using the additional time to slow down when covering concepts such as the CLT, joint distributions, etc. The final was also really hard. Mean squared error is very annoying to compute. Also, why didn't the practice final have solutions?

The professor of this course clearly did not care about the learning of his students. He rushed very quickly through his poor lectures and refused to slow down even when asked by numerous students to do so. Whenever a question was asked, rather than providing an answer he made it his job to make you feel stupid by letting you know that he believed the question you asked was dumb. He was not helpful and did not teach. There are no strengths about this course whatsoever. This class is a disgrace to the classes at Yale and is a disgrace to the Yale education.

Strengths: Probability is interesting, so any probability class is fun to study. 

Weaknesses: The topic is not easy, especially for those who are new to Math classes beyond Calculus and Linear Algebra. Lecture slides are not enough to fully understand the topic. You should put great effort trying to understand the topics by reading the book or searching summaries online. While attending lectures help to certain degree, they are not enough, even to understand 60% of the material presented in the given lecture. To address this issue, the Professor could put extra effort into offering books and online materials to study. The professor holds 2 hours of office hours every week, and there are some TA office hours. But not all TAs are good at teaching. In fact, it was noted that some TAs were not fluent in English and had hard time clearly explaining the topics. This leaves only a handful of office hours where you can learn the topic well. 2 hours with the Professor certainly helps, but in a class of 150+ students, it is not at all sufficient. In summary, the class did not have enough outside of lecture support, and as a student, I felt alone in my journey to understand Probability Theory properly. While I have been very passionate about the topic, I would have enjoyed my experience much more with proper care given by the Professors and instructors.

I thought the material was very interesting, but that the lectures were not engaging. Lecture notes were detailed and very helpful, so it was much easier to review lecture notes independently rather than go to class, where the instructor would reiterate lecture notes. I thought the problem sets reflected what we learned in class, and that the course was very well organized.

Strength: nothing
Weakness: format, teaching style, homework
Professor Wu often assumes prior knowledge even though this is a class that requires no background and can be an intro stats class. All of the topics were somehow unrelated through his teaching. I saw no connections between any of the topics. He liked to jump around. His teaching style is fast and inconsiderate. His responses make you feel like an absolute dumbass. By the end of the semester, I was too scared to ask him questions because he would literally make me feel like a dumbass. Homework topics also jumped around and often would not be relevant to what we learned in class. It would be helpful to make the homeworks categorized by week so that students even knew what they were practicing.
the most poorly run class I have ever taken
The professor wrote the worst final both in incompetence and unfathomable difficulty i have ever laid eyes on.

All of the material covered in this course is extremely relevant, the textbook is great, and the topics are interesting. Those are the only strengths of this course. The presentation of these topics, the teaching, and just about everything else are massive weaknesses. The professor's and TAs' disregard for the course, the failure of a higher-up administrator to intervene, and more are systemic weaknesses.

Weaknesses: professor, TAs, lectures, organization (or lack of)

Strengths: material is interesting, psets are satisfying once complete
Homeworks and midterms are quite straightforward and easy. However, the final is crazily hard. Most disheartening class I ever took at Yale.
The final was horrible; had no support going in, no answer keys to the practice exams, and some of the material was barely touched upon in lecture

The examples in class were extremely simple, but the ones assigned for homework and on tests were more than fairly difficult. This imbalance forced one to spend a lot of extra time learning material outside of class to be able to gather all of the nuance expected of you.

The first half of the course was very easy and the second half was very difficult. The lectures were not dynamic at all, and the problem sets could have been more difficult to be consistent with the exams, which were definitely harder.

The course did a good job of teaching the new content. However, the textbook used was often very unhelpful, as the textbook covered different things, even when using the matching chapters. The problem sets felt fair for the most part, although there were occasionally some questions that were either on content that had not been covered yet at the time of the posting of the problem set, or which were much more difficult than normal.
Its hard for me to separate the teacher from the class.

-The TAs were terrible. Their comments were never helpful and the way they both spoke did more harm than good. 
-The Professor was one of the least approachable I have ever seen in my academic career. He seemed as if he did not want to receive any questions. Half of the answers to my questions ended as "But is obvious. It is clearly stated in the slides." when of course it was not. 
-It was a good thing that the home works took up such a large percentage of the grade, since the final exam was a creation of the devil. 
-The final exam had almost no connection what so ever with what we did during the rest of the semester. No matter how many exercised I would solve, I would never had been ready for the final. The Professor was out of his mind. What exactly was the point of having such an impossible exam? It had no learning value and it only made us feel bad for our selves. The Professor should never be allowed in the history of time and existence to create an other exam. This single exam may have destroyed my entire GPA. I was so confident for this class. I had aced all of the home works and I had done great in the midterm. But no. All this effort had to be thrown out of the window with this horrendous exam. Such an exam is probably the reason that so many Yalies every year fall into depression or much worst decide to end their lives because they cannot meet the unrealistic expectations that this society has made us live up to. I hope to God that I never have to see any of the people who designed this exam in front of my eyes. Shame on you.
Very hard tests!! Problem sets were informative but did not line up with exams :(
There are no solutions to practice exams.

I liked the course content as well as the fact that lecture slides were always posted which made them easy to review. Problem sets also tended to be fairly challenging/time consuming but generally doable with sufficient effort. In terms of weaknesses, I think sometimes Professor Wu's explanations weren't the clearest and that the final was unrealistically challenging (it was too long to be completed in the allotted time and had some very confusing portions). Also having more resources for the final would definitely have been incredibly helpful (i.e. extra review sessions, posted solutions to practice finals, and so on).

Strengths: some of the material is interesting although very poorly

Weakness: PROFESSOR YIHONG WU is unbelievably awful. Like literally the worst professor I've ever seen. He does not care AT ALL about his students and is an awful professor. The idea of taking another class with him makes me want to transfer. Worst Professor doesn't deserve to be teaching.

The lectures are fairly clear but often dont give much help at all on how to approach homework or exam problems. Also a lack of answer keys to posted practice exams makes the practice exams pretty useless if you dont happen to be able to go to office hours to ask questions.

This course needs a different professor. Yihong is the worst professor at Yale, period.  He hates his students, doesnt help during office hours, is demoralizing, and only cares about his research.  Ive come to expect such amazing teachers at Yale, and this was a huge disappointment.  He can also barely speak English, and is partial to the Chinese students.  He didnt give us answers to the practice finals but gave the answers to the Chinese students.
Lectures were dry and not helpful over the slides. The content was interesting and useful, but PSET's were difficult and the Final Exam a leap above what we had been previously shown.

Horrid exam prep: Yihong gave us three years worth of finals to practice with, yet declined to provide even a single answer guide. Office hours were feeding frenzies, with dozens of kids crammed into the little stats building basement clamoring for help while the prof and TFs, who are literal career statisticians, assured us that the work was actually quite easy and we should just think back to high school calculus.

Overall I thought that the lecture slides and the discussion sections were very helpful. The main weakness of the course was that it is such a large lecture and classroom that it doesn't create the more intimate learning environment like other classes do.
Yihong was a dry lecturer (hard to show up) and made the midterm too easy so the final was unnecessarily hard
The course itself is fine, it's really easy for math majors and probably really hard for non math oriented people. The weakness of the course is its at 9am.

I think the first half of the course was very well thought. We maybe spent too much time explaining the simpler concepts in the beginning and as a result of this we didn't spend enough time going over the more complex ones covered towards the end of the class. I think in the second part of the class the professor was more focused towards covering all of the topics in the syllabus, than towards thoroughly explaining the concepts.
Office hours were terrible and did not help and the teacher was very inaccessible

Strengths: There is a lot of study material for students to work with.

Weaknesses: The lectures for this class were painfully dull. It was difficult to justify going to lectures when the professor was just narrating slides that were posted on canvas. The class is definitely hurt by its large size. While you'd think this should mean there are more people to get help from, the class isn't organized for this to occur - so try to take this class with a friend. The biggest weakness of the class was incredibly unclear expectations for what students should be capable of doing. The lectures would involve proofs and at times endless example problems that were totally irrelevant to the psets. The difficulty between the final and midterm (as well as the psets) was striking to a lot of students. While it's okay to have a difficult exam, the students should at least be able to expect what is coming so they can manage their time properly. Additionally, this disorganization at the end of the day has a negative impact on the students education. It was very difficult to focus on learning in this class when the graded work and lectures were organized the way they were.
The Prof was very impatient.

The problem sets were a little annoying and it was difficult to make myself attend the 9 am lectures when the notes were just as good. But otherwise the class was a good introduction to probability theory.

The course's strength is its comprehensive and detailed curriculum. It is your bread-and-butter college probability course. Having this sort of foundation is quite useful  and frankly, essential  for future quantitative work, including data analysis. The course is, on the other hand, too large in size. I did not come to know any of the other students well, nor even the undergraduate learning assistants (ULAs). The homework assignments and midterms paralleled the course material closely, while the final exam blindsided me in terms of the applications it asked of us, and the level of difficulty of the questions. The course material taught varies from year to year, and this is inevitable in any course. I was disappointed we didn't get to Markov chains, an application I was looking forward to. Overall a standard and strong theory course, but with some deficiencies in its basic homework-and-exam structure. More in-depth work, projects, and application-based analysis would enrich the course and provide better preparation for subsequent coursework.

I really liked that the class was deeply involved in solving relevant problems and examples. It illustrated daily the utility of probability and reinforced why I wanted to learn the subject. Solving problems and examples is the best way of learning and applying concepts. Problem sets were extremely illustrative and were core to my development in the class. Another major strength of the course was the clarity and thoroughness of Professor Wu in lecture, office hours and his slides. The textbook further reinforced class time and problem sets. It is evident that Professor Wu has an adept knowledge of probability, and his explanations illuminated the deeper mechanistic and intuitive theory driving our solutions. That depends. It's definitely not a walk in the park, and it's heavily theoretical with a lot of long calculations with lots of calculus, so I don't think many people would take it as an optional course. However, I do think that I gained a deeper understanding of probability, and the topics do seem foundational for a lot of further study in math, statistics, computer science, engineering, and even any other field that might use statistical methods, like biology/medicine. The 9:00am time slot was brutal, but Prof Wu's slides are amazing and he posts them on Canvas, and the TA and ULA office hours are a lifesaver. I usually spent 5-7 hours on the weekly problem sets, and I did them almost entirely at TA/ULA office hours because they're pretty difficult at first glance. Often after some guidance everything becomes clear, but then there is still a lot of calculus left (definitely brush up on your calculus before this course if you have a chance). It was really satisfying to finish the problem sets, though, and they were helpful for learning the concepts and studying for the exams. The singular midterm (in class) had surprisingly few questions, and while most of them were super manageable, one was very long and convoluted-- unless you'd heard of it (it turns out it was a popular math question) and knew the super easy trick. So that was a little annoying. At least they gave decent partial credit. The final exam was really brutal, though, which was a little unexpected after the easier midterm (but par for the course for Prof Wu based on the fall 2016 final which had a 60% average). I don't know the final exam average yet, but I don't think I was the only one who struggled and didn't even manage to write anything down for some of the questions.
